awd_titl_txt: RUI: Understanding Cu(I) Interactions with Zinc-Metalloproteins: Impact of Cu(I) on Structure and Function of the X-Linked Inhibitor of Apoptosis Protein
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program to Profesor Kathryn Splan of Macalester College supports research that investigates the interaction of copper ions with zinc-binding proteins. Many proteins require metal ions for proper function, and replacement of the usual metal ion with one exhibiting different chemical properties is likely to alter protein structure, and therefore, function. While metal-ion substitution has clear ramifications in the context of metal-ion toxicity, changes in protein function upon metal-ion substitution may also constitute a desirable functional strategy. The experiments reveal the susceptibility of zinc proteins toward substitution by copper and characterize the impact of this substitution on the protein's function. The project trains students in biochemical preparation and characterization techniques, thereby building solid technical skills in preparation for further study and/or entry into the work force. The results from the project also inform the fields of cell biology, neurochemistry, and neurobiology, particularly in those areas concerned with the molecular basis of diseases that are characterized by mis-regulated metal ion levels.

In this work, the impact of Cu(I) on metalloprotein function is further investigated by characterizing the interaction of Cu(I) with the X-linked Inhibitor of Apoptosis Protein (XIAP), a Zn(II)-metalloprotein recently implicated in copper homeostasis. Multiple Zn(II) protein structural motifs have been shown to be susceptible to displacement by Cu(I), owing to the shared thiophilic character of both metal ions. Cu(I) substitution at the Zn(II) structural sites of XIAP is one possible mechanism by which XIAP function may be modulated by changing copper concentrations. A variety of spectroscopic and biochemical approaches are utilized to detect the displacement of zinc ions upon the addition of copper and the resulting structural and functional changes. Understanding Cu(I) interactions with this target at the molecular level deepens the understanding of metalloprotein susceptibility toward disruption by Cu(I) in general and clarifies the role of Cu(I) in XIAP function.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Many proteins bind metal ions to ensure proper structure and function. Disruption of the metal binding site(s) via substitution with other metal ions constitutes a putative mechanism for both metal ion toxicity and modulation of biomolecule function in response to changing metal ion concentrations. Metal ion complexes are also routinely explored as potential therapeutics owing to their ability to modulate biomolecule function. In this context, we and other research groups have explored the impact of copper ions on zinc metalloprotein structure and function. Both copper in its reduced form and zinc have a high affinity for protein binding sites that utilize thiol groups to coordinate metal ions.  While it is apparent that copper ions can displace zinc under some conditions, the impact of the substitution on protein function is not well understood.

With this award, we studied the interaction of copper with a portion of the X-linked Inhibitor of Apoptosis Protein (XIAP), which, in addition to its regulatory role in programed cell death may also function to control copper levels in cells. We show that the zinc-containing RING domain of XIAP binds multiple copper ions, resulting in zinc ejection and loss of the dimeric protein structure that is required for proper function. This modulation of protein structure by copper ions may provide a molecular mechanism by which XIAP responds to changing copper levels within cells. We also investigated the interaction of oxidized copper with zinc binding proteins and peptides. While reduced copper is the predominant form of copper under cellular conditions, oxidized copper may be present under conditions of copper dis-regulation or when incorporated into complexes intended to act as drugs. We show that copper binding by zinc-containing peptides and proteins results in copper reduction and zinc ejection, demonstrating the zinc protein sites are susceptible to modulation by multiple forms of copper. We also show that via this mechanism, zinc binding sites sequester copper in a form that cannot produce reactive oxygen species that can lead to cell death, providing a mechanism by which zinc proteins might attenuate the activity of copper- based drugs.

In addition to the scientific contributions described above, the award provided rigorous biochemical training experiences for undergraduate students at Macalester College. Six undergraduate students participated in summer research experiences that resulted in the outcomes above, and three continued their work during the academic year(s) as independent study. Students also gained communication skills by presenting their research at local and/or international meetings, and two students based their senior honors theses on the projects. The skills acquired via focused research experiences contributes to the professional training of the students and prepares them for further study or entrance into the scientific workforce.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Kathryn Splan
